citation.name: J. Biol. Chem.
citation.title: Structure of a construct of a human poly(C)-binding protein containing the first and second KH domains reveals insights into its regulatory mechanisms.

comment.text: Single-stranded nucleic acid binding protein that binds preferentially to oligo dC. Major cellular poly(rC)-binding protein. Binds also poly(rU). Negatively regulates cellular antiviral responses mediated by MAVS signaling (PubMed:19881509). It acts as an adapter between MAVS and the E3 ubiquitin ligase ITCH, therefore triggering MAVS ubiquitination and degradation (PubMed:19881509).

(Microbial infection) In case of infection by poliovirus, binds to the viral internal ribosome entry site (IRES) and stimulates the IRES-mediated translation (PubMed:12414943, PubMed:24371074). Also plays a role in initiation of viral RNA replication in concert with the viral protein 3CD (PubMed:12414943).

Identified in a mRNP complex, at least composed of DHX9, DDX3X, ELAVL1, HNRNPU, IGF2BP1, ILF3, PABPC1, PCBP2, PTBP2, STAU1, STAU2, SYNCRIP and YBX1. Interacts with IFIH1 and RNF135. Interacts with MAVS (via C-terminus) and ITCH (via WW domains).
Loosely bound in the nucleus. May shuttle between the nucleus and the cytoplasm.
The KH domains mediates poly(C) binding.
Phosphorylated. The non-phosphorylated form(s) exhibited the strongest poly(rC)-binding activity.
(Microbial infection) Proteolyticaly cleaved by picornavirus proteinase 3CD.

property.value: Expressed in testis and 243 other tissues
P:negative regulation of defense response to virus
P:negative regulation of type I interferon production
